title: Badandun Hill
text:
Route up


A short drive back down the road, and parking on the verge before the roadway entrance across the river, I was off on the next summit. This route isn‚Äôt the greatest, and was only picked for it‚Äôs short duration and short drive to the starting point. It starts out easy enough following the track and then crossing the field. It briefly follows a path that you could take the whole way up to the top, just a little longer. You have to jump the Fergus Burn, but it‚Äôs quite small in places, and then you start the slog straight up the hill to the summit.






After the sleeting on the way down from Monamenach, the sky was even clearer now, and I had good views back and forwards of my hills for the day.
Whilst the walk up was steep enough, it went by quickly and I was soon leaning into the wind on the summit. There wasn‚Äôt much shelter by the trig point, and the top hole was covered, but I did find the mast mount which happened to be behind a slight rise, so that offered as little relief. Making full use of the post, I felt very smart when I took this photo.



Lovely station


and then this‚Ä¶



Sad pole


At that moment it was very obvious that I should‚Äôve attached the mast on the leeward side of the support, so the metal post didn‚Äôt act like my leg when I break sticks over it. ü§¶

I collapsed the mast enough to get past the break and continued on 2m. Three repeat stations from the first summit, and another got it qualified and then I was ‚Äúhappy‚Äù to pack up and grump down the hillside back to the car. Luckily, I had packed a spare mast in the car.

On to the next hill!

title: Carn a‚ÄôMhaim
text:
After the lovely weekend‚Äôs weather, I was watching the forecast and today‚Äôs was looking good, so I decided to take the day off work and go for a big trip in the Cairngorms. Unfortunately, by the time it got to today, the weather wasn‚Äôt quite as nice as originally forecast. It was mild though, 12 degC at the Linn of Dee when I set off in the morning.



Cycle through the forest





Path to Derry Lodge, Carn a Mhaim in the clouds at the back


I started at Linn of Dee, and cycled along the nice track to Derry Lodge, a now boarded up hunting lodge. It‚Äôs common for people to leave their bikes here as the paths beyond aren‚Äôt quite as nice, or people are doing the big loop around Derry Cairngorm, Ben Macdui and back, and this is where all the paths return to. My route today did have a loop but not as big, and I continued to cycle on to Luibeg burn.



Derry Lodge Bridge


After crossing the bridge, the ground soon beomes very muddy and boggy, with the bike wheels disappearing half way into the mud. It was hard work finding a path across, but once that was done the track was reasonable again. There were some surface drains across the path but they were wide and easy to cycle over, but as I neared Luibed these became more rocky and less navigable whilst cycling. I reached Luibeg and wanted to leave my bike near the bridge, as this would be where I‚Äôd be coming on the way back.



Luibeg Bridge - I was approaching from the right and heading to the left on this map


There are actually three routes from east to west from when you meet the trees at Luibeg. I‚Äôd planned to take the upper route, ended up on the lower route, and found that the middle one would‚Äôve been best! I ended up trying to get my bike through the woods on a tiny track, with rocks and roots and all sorts. It was not easy, but I eventually made it to the bridge. I left my bike there, crossed the bridge and walked down to rejoin the path before taking the northern split to ascent Carn a Mhaim. As I was walking up I realised I‚Äôd lost my LoRa tracker somewhere in those woods. It was on the top of my bag and the trees must‚Äôve knocked it off. üò¢ It wasn‚Äôt on as there are no igates nearby and I‚Äôm in the valley, so it‚Äôs not like I can even track the tracker!



Luibeg Bridge - the alternative to fording the burn





Looking back the way I came along Glen Lui


As I climbed I entered the cloud and the lovely views all disappeared. The walk up was steep but straightforward.



In the cloud


Then out of the mist the summit cairn appeared and I setup for my first activation of the day. I‚Äôd hoped to qualify the summit on 2m, so I could get moving, but being mid-week I wasn‚Äôt hopeful. I did get three 2m QSOs fairly quickly, and then set up the quick 5.5m vertical for 20m. Contacts came in quick with that and then I thought I heard Bill, GM0NRT, call on 20m but I think it was on the HT still and then in my confusion the chasers stopped. However, I had enough contacts so just packed up. As I was doing so, Denis, MM0CBC, was out on a summit further west near Aviemore and he‚Äôd just reached the top. We had a tricky QSO as Bill thought I was speaking to him still on 2m, he struggled to hear me but heard me asking Denis to QSY, again thinking it was me asking Bill to QSY! Denis couldn‚Äôt hear Bill so it was probably confusing for him too but we made it in the end. As I was chatting with Denis, a lady came by to the summit. She was curious as to what I was doing and we had a brief chat. She then left and continued up to Ben Macdui. I packed up and started towards it myself.



At the summit





Station setup


The path that continues towards Ben Macdui follows the ridge between the two glens until it gets to the side of the mountain. This is quite a narrow ridge, but thankfully the wind was gentle. The clouds did start to part and I had a few glimpses down into Lairig Ghru, including Corrour bothy at the foot of Cairn Toul and Devil‚Äôs Point climb.



Corrour Bothy





Ridge to Ben Macdui


Then on to Ben Macdui!

title: Waughton Hill
text:
The 145 Alive! event was planned for today between 1-3pm, which I wanted to join in with. Should be the perfect time to activate a summit on 2m! I had the three little kids with me for the day, so it had to be a easy summit. Particularly as I wanted to bring up the tent and lunch and things for them, to keep them entertained whilst I was on the air. The previous times I‚Äôve brought them, I‚Äôve only been about 20 minutes at most and trying to go much longer would be tricky. Eventually I want to qualify all the GM/ES summits, and so Waughton hill is on my list. It‚Äôs quite out of the way with nothing else nearby, so it‚Äôs a trip in itself and for one point, I‚Äôm not wasting a day off on it! It‚Äôs also the lowest summit in GM/ES, and seemed perfect for our adventure.



White Horse


The path up is short, although does cross a field full of cows, and you soon find yourself by the white horse. Walk by its head and you‚Äôre on the top of the rise, and heading towards the old hunter‚Äôs cottage. The actual summit is a bit further away, requiring you to go down and up the side of the hill again. However, the hunter‚Äôs cottage is in the activation zone and the kids thought we‚Äôd reached the top and started playing in the house. There was also a nice piece of grass without any sheep or animal droppings on it for the tent I‚Äôd brought. The tent and mast went up easily enough and lunch and various toys were unloaded into the tent. It was about 12:55 and I wanted to be on the air for the start of the event, so I swallowed down my rolls and setup the IC-705. Turns out the coax on the slim G with the 6m tactical mini mast is just a little too short for the radio to be on the ground. I usually don‚Äôt notice as either using the carbon 6, where the antenna sits a little lower on it, or a HT which I‚Äôm holding at standing height. So I ended up having to hold the 705 in my hand the whole time.



Station setup


I‚Äôve not long had the IC-705 and whilst it is very simple to use, sometimes I get into some modes or settings that I don‚Äôt know how to get out of. Today I was already on 2m FM but would the VFO change the frequency? No.¬†First I was worried I‚Äôd bashed it in my bag and the dial was broken, then thought perhaps I‚Äôd selected 10 or 100 Hz increment but that didn‚Äôt seem to matter. I ended up just pressing stuff and then going to band and choosing 144 MHz again seemed to fix it. Phew!



QSOs


It was nice having the waterfall to see is there was any activity and there certainly was some! I knew MM0EFI and MM0RFN were going up Ben Macdui and Glas Maol respectively, but not sure if they‚Äôd got to the summit in time. Fraser was supposed to be on 145.250, so I tuned to it and heard Bill, GM0NRT, talking to someone but couldn‚Äôt hear the other end. I was worried I couldn‚Äôt hear Fraser on Ben Macdui, but turned out was just someone else. Tuning around, I heard a guy down at the car park by Hill of Garvock and ended up qualifying the summit with those on his net. I managed to work four summit to summits, two on Ben Macdui, Glas Maol and then Morven. I heard a station down in East Lothian calling on 145.500 but he didn‚Äôt hear my reply. After about an hour, I had 10 QSOs and thought it was about time we packed up.



Off to Aden Country Park


We headed back down, and went to Aden Country Park for some more fun. Turned out to be an old timey tractor fair and there were loads of them on the roads as we drove there.
Was a fun day all round, and nice to join in with this event. Maybe next time I‚Äôll try for a higher summit!
The guys up Ben Macdui had a fun trip.. Not jealous in the slightest‚Ä¶üòÖ Also afterwards, Chris, 2M0RVZ, was boasting about his points compared to mine‚Ä¶challenge accepted!

title: Brown Cow Hill
text:
Tim, GM5OLD, is up in the area and doing a few summits. I took the opportunity (with kind support from the family‚Ä¶for the morning at least!) to be out at the same time for some S2S action. Tim was going up both Mona Gowan and Morven today, and so I picked a 4-pointer nearby - the very Scottish sounding, Brown Cow Hill.



Corgarff Castle


The route starts in the car park for Corgarff castle and takes a nice track up the hill. Weather was okay, some low cloud and the possibility of rain in the afternoon. Our rendezvous time was around 10-10:30am. After my previous epic journey up two high peaks, this felt like a walk in the park. There was almost no wind and that alone made it enjoyable.



Watchers


I soon entered the cloud and visibility dropped considerably. This was fine whilst I was following the track but after a while it mostly disappears into the heather‚Ä¶and peat hags.



Mist





Peat hags





and more peat hags


There must‚Äôve been some serious water coming down as the channels carved by it were huge, I had to make quite a few detours to find crossable areas without having to scramble down a muddy cliff face. It was wet and boggy underfoot, and I had plenty of full foot submersions.



New fence


Near the top, I emerged from the cloud and could enjoy some of the scenery again. A very new looking fence seemed to cross across the path but luckily a gate was nearby, so I didn‚Äôt have to clamber over it. Being out of the mist, I was rewarded with some lovely views across to nearby summits, including Ben Avon I recently did. There wasn‚Äôt any snow at the top of them any more, they were out of the cloud and probably enjoyed the minimal wind as I was. Today would‚Äôve been a much better day to climb them! If I did have the whole day, it would‚Äôve been good to try Ben Macdui or some of the other high peaks too.



Culardoch to the south





A sunny summit - not sure which, Morrone?





Ben Avon and Beinn a‚ÄôBhuird (perhaps South Top)


I reached the summit about 10am and setup my mast with the slim G and sloper L random wire antenna. The complete lack of wind was so enjoyable, although I still managed not to fully extend the mast and it collapsed on me! I knew Tim was nearly at the top too, so once setup I just listened to the bands and had something to eat. Unfortunately, just at the moment the cloud came in and the lovely views disappeared - oh well!



Not much of a cairn





Station setup


I brought the G90 and 4Ah LiFePO4 battery today. I like the G90, it‚Äôs a bit heavier than the KX2, but as my first radio, I have a soft spot for it. It‚Äôs pretty capable, especially given the price, and 20W and a tuner than can match the 5.5m vertical random wire on 40m is pretty sweet. 20W over 10W probably makes no discernible difference, but I do like the little waterfall for finding quiet spots on the band. If I‚Äôm going on a long walk, and multiple summits, I‚Äôd probably stick with the KX2. If the weather is bad, I‚Äôd lean more to the KX2 also, as its form factor makes it easier to keep hidden from the rain in my shadow or a plastic bag. However, on a short walk, and nice weather, I‚Äôd probably take the G90, or if I just want a change.



QSOs


I had some nice QSOs with Tim, GM5OLD, Fraser, MM0EFI, and Chris, 2M0RVZ, on 2m. I could hear Bill, GM0NRT, in Aberdeen about a 31, but he couldn‚Äôt hear me. Tim had Bill as a 59, but it seemed Mona Gowan/Morven were enough to block my signal. Tim and I had a nice chat for a while, on 145.500, but there‚Äôs no-one around here so it doesn‚Äôt matter üòÖ, and then we both went to HF. Plenty of contacts on 40m, in England, Ireland and into Europe. I hunted a few summit to summits, with a pair in Italy and one in Norway. I moved up to 10m, a band I‚Äôve not tried much, usually as I‚Äôm in a rush and once the summit is qualified I‚Äôm off, and got several more stations in Europe and a couple into ‚ÄúAfrica‚Äù, the Canary Islands, receiving 55 and 59 from them.



Views to the north


I was meant to be home by 1pm but I was having a blast on the air, and the weather was pleasant, so I ended up staying at the summit for much longer than I planned. However, I did have to get back, so I packed up and headed down. I tried walking a straight route from crossing the fence back to the main track, but managed to wind all over the place. There did seem to be fewer peat hags on the way back, although the few that there were, they were a lot steeper. I also managed to miss the turning on the track back to the castle and looked up to find the castle much higher than me, so then scrambled up the side of the slope to get back on the proper track. At this point it started to rain a little but I was nearly back to the car.
I‚Äôm only the 8th person to activate Brown Cow Hill. It‚Äôs clearly not a popular summit, and likely one for just those looking to complete GM/ES or other lists. There are plenty of other ones nearby that are more appealing. However, if the weather is clear, you get some stunning views all around, and the walk up isn‚Äôt that bad - around 6.6 km and 425m ascent, with minimal ups and downs - just the peat hags to deal with but other summits have those too. I still stand by that Morven is the worst summit for brutality of ascent!
Here‚Äôs Fraser at the other end of our 2m QSO.

title: Beinn a‚ÄôChaorainn
text:
Continuing my journey from Beinn Mheadoin‚Ä¶
It was pretty much downhill and then back up. It was now about 1230 and I was a little behind schedule, but enjoying the sun and rainbows. I looked back over to Mheadoin and, typically, now it was in the sun too!



Across to Chaorainn





üåà





Beinn Mheadoin in the sun


The climb up Beinn a‚ÄôChaorainn starts quite steep with loose gravel but soon turns into a nice climb, aside from the boulder patch, but you can mostly work around it. As I got higher the wind picked up again. The summit cairn didn‚Äôt look very impressive, but actually offered decent shelter and I was quite comfortable behind it.



At the summit





Station (in the process of being dismantled!)


This time I tried 20m and the band was much more enjoyable, with a strong signal everywhere between south of England and Greece around 1,700 miles away.
Denis, MM0CBC on holiday from Wales, was on his way up Ben Tinnes, GM/ES-021, and by the time I was done with HF he was just setting up there, so we had a nice 2m S2S.
It was 1345 and I really needed to be back at Linn of Dee by 1530, to get home in time, so after getting distracted taking more photos, I hot stepped it back down and retrieved my bike. A reasonable number of other cyclists and hikers out, I didn‚Äôt meet any on the summits but along the main routes. It seemed now was the best weather of the day and plnety to enjoy as I cycled back.



Sun shining on Beinn Mheadoin





Looking back up the Glen - Beinn Mheadoin at the back


Back at Linn of Dee at exactly 1530, and then the 1.5 hours drive back to Aberdeen. There was a huge moon and the road back to Braemar offered some lovely views of the moon between the trees and hills, together with the start of the sunsetting, my potato photo doesn‚Äôt do it justice.



Big moon


Another big trip, probably the last of this year, unless there‚Äôs a December heat wave, and two infrequently visited and activated summits. It‚Äôs hard not to be biased by the weather but Beinn a‚ÄôChaorainn was my favourite today. When the clouds cleared I could see over to Beinn a‚ÄôBhuird area, down to Beinn Bhreac and big sweeping expanses of hillsides. It would‚Äôve been nice to have been on Beinn Mheadhoin when the cloud lifted to see across to the west, and probably that would‚Äôve been more spectacular. I‚Äôll be revisiting them both next year, hopefully finding a day with clear blue skies! üåû
Also posted on the reflector.

title: Carn a‚ÄôGheoidh
text:
After a lovely day yesterday on Lochnagar and Conachcraig, I was looking to see where I could go today. There was a swimming competition on, in addition to the usual activities, so I needed to be back for 3pm. Last week when I was on An Socach, the others went to Carn a‚ÄôGheoidh, and I remembered them leaving later than me but arriving at the top at the same time. Sure enough when I check all the times, it looked doable to get there and back in time. The longest part is the drive to Glenshee ski centre, and that‚Äôs right at the limit of the electric car - returning home with 20 miles range still makes me a little nervous!



A grey day


The weather forecast had it cloudy with chance of showers and reasonably breezy. It did rain a little on the way out but was dry when I arrived. I wasted about 10 minutes getting a parking ticket from the cafe - I should‚Äôve just opened the link in the car park when I was up the hill and had signal, like I did with Glas Maol.



Look, snow!


The track follows up the ski maintenance tracks, which are quite steep to start. There‚Äôs a shortcut across part way up which I just walked right past. My Inreach mini started beeping as I‚Äôd gone of course and so I backtracked and found it. It was a small track at right angles to the main path just behind a fence, so not too obvious, so thanks to the Garmin!



Navigation via Inreach Mini


I was soon in the cloud and did check on the inreach every so often to make sure I was heading in the right direction. I doesn‚Äôt have topo maps, and just a line but it has a compass and so points in the right direction and is enough to make sure you‚Äôre following the right path.



Cloudy


I didn‚Äôt see much on the way up, other than about 20m around me, mostly looking like the photo. In exposed places the wind picked up a lot and gave me a good push. At one point I was about 3m from a small loch and I didn‚Äôt realise until I was right upon it. The track was decent and only in a few places was it boggy but nothing like The Buck. The final ascent to the summit is steep again after a while of walking on the mostly flat plateau. At this point the wind was howling and I was glad there was a cairn at the top.



Made it!


I setup behind the cairn, which was a very good shelter from the wind, had a sandwich and then got on the air. I thought I‚Äôd try a bit more power on 2m and see if I could get any further than usual. I‚Äôd brought the Kenwood V71 and battery. This is the first time I‚Äôve taken it out with me, and I also haven‚Äôt used it much at home, so I was hoping I wouldn‚Äôt get into any operating issues with it! I had the slim G, and was glad I hadn‚Äôt brought the yagi to try and setup in the wind.



Wind battered carbon mast





Kenwood V71, trying to keep dry


I now wonder if I‚Äôd setup the mast on the outside of the cairn pointing into the wind, if I could‚Äôve made it more vertical. Particularly as right at the end the antenna got blown off and I ended up holding it with my arm to finish the QSO - I didn‚Äôt do an EMF assessment on that setup‚Ä¶



QSOs


It was a little slow to start, but eventually I‚Äôd work 9 stations, including GM4OAS 90 miles to the west in Mallaig. I did find the lowest squelch on the V71 was quite high and not breaking for several stations. I eventually turned it off and then heard several locals and others. I do wonder how many had been replying to my CQs before. Did 50W make any difference? The map looks remarkably similar to when I was on Glas Maol, and that was with the 5W D72 handheld. Technically, it‚Äôs 10 dB which is 1.x S points, and on Glas Maol GM4OAS gave me 32 and this time he gave me 42, so whilst not more power, I was readable more? I do like the form factor of using the mobile rig with the fist mic, means I can position things easier than being tied directly to the end of the mast, but probably for the most part it makes no real difference and it‚Äôs all in my head!



Cloud clearing‚Ä¶for a moment


Keeping an eye on the time, I needed to pack up and head back. The wind was still relentless and on the top I had to lean into it. I was grateful of my big hood as I followed the path back down. It‚Äôs amazing how you can forget some of the details of the walk on the way back, being surprised that I had to climb up and down a few places which I didn‚Äôt remember on the way up to the summit! For a few moments the wind seemed to blow the clouds away and there was even a hint of sunshine coming through. The view opened up and I could see all around. Certainly not the spectacular views of last week, but enjoyable for the few moments. Back down to the car and back home.



Lift to the clouds


I think this summit and Glas Maol would make a nice day trip out, one in the morning and one in the afternoon, with the option of a hot lunch at the ski centre cafe. For 6 and 8 pointers, they have fairly easy and short walks, and both great locations for 2m, particularly to the south. Doing both would be 14 points, and a lot less walking and climbing than my 14 point day yesterday on Lochnagar and Conachcraig!

title: Beinn Mheadhoin
text:
The weather has been lovely up here all week - next week, however less so‚Ä¶



Mountain Forecast


So I wanted to make the most of it, and took today off. Monday or Tuesday were better days but alas I couldn‚Äôt make that happen. As you can see the forecast was meant to be lovely clear skies and maybe some cloud creeping in later. Well it was the opposite, with the best weather as I was cycling back‚Ä¶oh well. Here we go:



Route for the day. Light blue section is mostly cycling.


Last week I did GM/ES-001 and GM/ES-013 on a big bike and hike, and today would be similar. I had debated between Cairn Toul + Braeriach and the two summits today, but everyone told me Cairn Toul circuit was too much, and save that for a summer‚Äôs day (or maybe camp in the Corrour bothy at the bottom). They‚Äôd all done the route so I should probably listen‚Ä¶and eventually I did. I‚Äôm glad, because it would‚Äôve been too long, and the weather wasn‚Äôt the best - particularly the wind - and so that wouldn‚Äôt have been enjoyable.



Crossing Lui Water





Bridge at Derry Lodge


Starting at Linn of Dee car park, around 0830, I cycled on the nice track to Derry Lodge. Here my route would take me east following the Derry Burn up Glen Derry. This section of the track is not great for cycling on, lots of roots, rocks, narrow sections with overhanging heather. It was slow going, much slower than I planned. Once you get to the next bridge and a few 10s metres along it‚Äôs much better. Some maps show an ATV track that runs somewhat parallel to this route. I didn‚Äôt see the start of it, but wondered if it would be better. Near the bridge you see it, and I did try it on the way back but it was very boggy, muddy and wet, and quick to disappear, so I just stuck to what I knew. The return run is less bad, as at least you‚Äôre generally going downhill.



This is not the path to cycle





Looking up Derry Glen to the summits


The cycling continues along the track, and once you pass the final wooded area it starts to become rocky and difficult again. I started pushing my bike through the bad sections but they just became more and more, and it wouldn‚Äôt save time as I‚Äôd have to push it on the way back. So I dumped the bike in the heather and continued up to the Y junction.



Bike left here


It was about 09:40, so 1-1:10 of cycling. My route was left at the Y, following the Coire Etchachan burn, past Hutchison Memorial hut and to the shores of little loch Etchachan.



Footbridge over Coire Etchachan burn





Up to the loch, bothy on the left


I had a peak inside the bothy and looked through the visitors book. Always interesting the little odds and ends people have left for others. Actually my first time in a bothy, would be fun one time‚Ä¶as long as I remembered to bring firewood!



Bothy





Memorial Plaque





Inside the bothy


Now the climb really started, and this brought the wind with it. It was relentless, reaching the peak at the top by the Loch.
I‚Äôd hoped the wind was just strong in the valley, and coming off the loch and that the summit would be better. Perhaps hoping in vain of course. The weather was not the clear skies forecast but very grey clouds, that I was about to be walking through. Not sure if it was raining or the wind just pushing huge volumes of air against me and the resultant water condensing made it seem like it was raining, but I was pretty wet all over.



Arriving at the lochs





Path up to Beinn Mheadhoin


Eventually a tor appeared out of the cloud and I thought I‚Äôd made it‚Ä¶looking at my map I realised it wasn‚Äôt and I still had some way to go. The next one appeared and I climbed up on top, but that was pushing it in the wind, and so I decided not to climb anymore. I thought the tors would shelter me from the wind but it seemed to come around from every direction and there was nowhere sheltered. I setup the mast and long wire, as I planned to start with 40m. I had the wrong guy ring for the carbon 6 and so it kept sliding all the way down, plus the peg into the wind kept lifting. I ended up putting three of the guys into the wind, plus pegging down the wire into the wind and it reached some equilibrium and held in place. It did remind me of the wacky waving inflatable arm flailing tube men.



‚ÄúEnjoying it‚Äù


40m wasn‚Äôt great, lots of QSB and I didn‚Äôt hang around long. Time for summit #2. Packed up and headed down into the Lairig an Laoigh. The sun was starting to peak through and once I was on the descent the wind abated. I took quite a direct route down, which was very steep and probably not the best route, although not sure where would‚Äôve been better.
Read on for Beinn a‚ÄôChaorainn.
Also posted on the SOTA reflector. Following the discussion there, it turns out my route from Derry Lodge was not the best one when cycling. In fact, not crossing the Derry Burn at the lodge and continuing on the east side until I got to the foot bridge would‚Äôve been a better cycle path - oh well, I know for next time!

title: Bennachie - Oxen Craig
text:
I‚Äôve chased a few SOTA activators before, it‚Äôs quite a fun thing to do, you watch the spotting website and then see if you can get them. Once someone posts a spot it‚Äôs pretty quick for them to get a pile up. I‚Äôve kept thinking about doing it, and I do live in an ideal place where there are plenty of summits to chose from. I‚Äôve not been on the radio much this year and I ended up taking a day off today to drop off and pick up the kids from school, so I decided I should make the most of it and go up a mountain!
Using the great SOTA map website, Sotlas, I had a look around to see where I should go first. As I was doing the school run, I was limited on time to about 6 hours all in. I also thought I shouldn‚Äôt try too much on my first attempt, in both walking and radio setup. I noticed that some summits get bonus points during the winter (between about December and March), and one of those was near me so I thought that would be ideal. The place is called Bennachie, and one of its highest peaks is Oxen Craig. The peaks are call a ‚Äòtap‚Äô. This is the summit GM/ES-061, which is worth two points and five in the winter.
As you can see from this photo taken by MM7MWL, it‚Äôs a beautiful view.

title: Bennachie - Oxen Craig
text:
Gear
Radio-wise, I still have my Xiegu G90, which was my first radio, that is portable enough ‚Äì certainly when compared to the Yaesu FTDX10! It‚Äôs got a bit of heft to it (2.5 kg üò∞), but is 20W, has a great ATU and a nice waterfall.
For the antenna, I wanted to keep it as simple as possible and to make use of my carbon 6m mast. I found MM0EFI‚Äôs random wire suggestion and it looked ideal. This is 5.5m radiator, with two 4.25m counterpoises. They‚Äôre attached via bananaplugs to a BNC, then a short piece of coax with a common mode choke into the radio.
The battery situation isn‚Äôt ideal. I‚Äôm using an ultramax 18 Ah LiFePO4 battery, which has loads of capacity and much better than a lead acid or a LiPo one but it‚Äôs still around 2.5 kg. I use it when out in the garden, but have never had to carry it very far. I do have a few 18650 lithium cells which I‚Äôm meaning to make my own portable battery but I‚Äôve not got round to it yet. So the ultramax had to do.
I also brought my Boafeng 2m/70cm radio to try some 2m FM. I have a Kenwood TH-D72, which I thought of bringing for APRS, but it‚Äôs too complex for my liking. Plus I could‚Äôve just used my phone for APRS if I really wanted to.
All in, with lunch and water, my backpack was over 6 kg. Fine, but plenty of room for optimisation next time.

title: Bennachie - Oxen Craig
text:
The Activation
With the kids dropped off at school, and backpack packed, I set off about 0915 to drive to the car park behind the summit.



At the car park


I wasn‚Äôt sure how long everything was going to take, so I opted to find the shortest and most direct route to the summit. There are quite a few walks you can do in the area via various taps and approach from different sides, but starting at the ‚Äúback‚Äù looked the quickest. It was basically a straight up.
I had looked at doing two activations in one trip, as Millstone Hill, GM/ES-077, isn‚Äôt that far away. However, when I worked out a couple of routes they were 4-5 hours of walking and I decided that was trying to do too much in one day.



Route planned on OS Maps





Straight up 350m over 2.2km (or 1,150 ft over 1.4 miles)


I paid my parking at 0953, and was being blown away on the summit by 1040, which was a bit quicker than the 1:08 hrs OSMaps suggested it would take to walk up. I was pretty hot and sweaty by the time I got to the top, and had taken off my hat, but once exposed in the wind, I was glad to have it.



Looking North





Up we go



It was quite nice weather on the way up, I could see the summits were under cloud cover, and when I reached the top the wind was howling and the air was very cold.



Cloud





View from the top


I looked around for a nice place to setup, and ate my sandwich. Another guy came up and we said hello. I tried a few calls on 145.500 MHz, but I think I would‚Äôve needed to organise this ahead of time with the locals. I found a nice outcrop to shelter behind that was in front of the summit, and setup the pole and radio on a rock. I had a little nook to crouch in and there I started to see if I could make any contacts.



Radio Setup


I started on 40m, had a listen to 10m, but it seemed dead, then moved to 15m and then finally 20m. I managed 37 contacts, with 14 countries, two summit to summit QSOs, and one parks on the air contact. My furthest contact was with Z36T in The Republic of North Macedonia at 1501 miles.



Map (partial) from SOTA database


I‚Äôd been on the air 50 minutes and my logging hand was getting cold! Plus I was getting stiff in my funny crouching position, and concious of getting back in time to pick up the kids. I was using Cloudlogoffline app to log, which is handy as it can then sync to my cloudlog database but I don‚Äôt like that it doesn‚Äôt keep the frequency from the previous QSO as the default entry. [update: you can under the settings, so set it there before starting to add QSOs.] It‚Äôs also fiddly to add another SOTA reference due to the iOS keyboard coming up when you select an input box and not being able to scroll. I might just do ‚ÄòFast Log Entry‚Äô (FLE) next time in an Apple note file. I‚Äôll see what else there is too. VK port-a-log seems to be a favourite for SOTA but it‚Äôs Android only.
I was back in time for a nice cup of tea and sit down before it was school pick up. I look forward to the next one. It‚Äôs fun being the DX! üìª‚õ∞Ô∏è

title: Mount Battock
text:
This is the most the most easterly Corbett, which make it the most easterly mountain in Scotland. The weather was absolutely lovely, although the forecast for the summit was high winds.



Clachnaben view from the start


The route was a long cycle, around 1:30, including pushing it up much of the steep parts to have a quick journey home. The path is very well made up the whole way, but you just have to watch you take the right turns at a few locations.



Was it left or right?



I dropped my bike at the turn off to the summit. As I approached the summit the wind was picking up considerably, I could also smell and see a lot of smoke in the air. Seemed to be some fires to the south, but at times the wind would blow great clouds of it towards me and it were as if I was right to a bonfire.



Fires





Looking north with view of path from the summit


This is a good summit for 2m, I think Fraser has done a 145 Alive event from here, and from looking at past logs on sotlas, so I was hoping for a quick activation on 2m. It wasn‚Äôt quite as quick as I‚Äôd hoped, but also turned out my spot didn‚Äôt really work properly, and showed as Test, due to the changes to the SOTA API and SOTAGoat not being updated.



At the top, in the wind!


However, my first CQ, with just the RH-770 telescopic antenna on, was immediately replied by G6BIA from South Shields, outside Newcastle, at 235 km/146 miles away! Great signal! It took another 30 minutes to get the 3 more needed to qualify and then one more from Hibby, MM0RFN, who met Fraser, MM0EFI, for lunch in Westhill.

Some good shelter on the summit - thank goodness - but also lots of fences and posts for future antenna mounting options! A good summit to spend the day if the weather co-operates.



Slim G in the air


Descent was quick, thanks to pushing the bike up so much of the ascent. Some parts were a bit hairy - steep, loose gravel and gusty winds, but once I was a little lower it was some nice free wheeling much of the way. It‚Äôs also a nice close summit, only being about 30 minutes drive from my house.



More views from the top

title: Carn a‚ÄôBhodaich
text:
We were up in Inverness for a swimming competition and I wondered if there were any summits I could manage. Luckily this one is only about 15 minutes from the pool and a fairly short walk up to the top. I dropped off for warm up and then headed up the hill. I‚Äôd read it was a bit of a soggy climb, and after the storm the past few days, there was a lot of water around. The path was more like a stream and in places there was deep standing water. It really only got better when climbing to the final top.



Summit in the distance





Fallen tree on the path


The final section of the walk doesn‚Äôt really have a path up to the summit, the track just continues around the hill and away, so it was a case of scrambling up the heather and trying to avoid the streams coming down. It was cold but still on the way up, but as soon as I was on the summit the wind was strong. I found a low spot with a post and some shelter and setup on 20m there. As I wanted to be quick, I was going for the 5.5m vertical with counterpoises.



At the top





Station location


Not too busy on 20m, but enough in the log with 9 QSOs. I packed up and headed down the way I came and back to Inverness.
Some good views of the hills from the summit and from the parking area. I‚Äôll come back next time I‚Äôm in the area, particularly if it‚Äôs during winter bonus!
